articles.headline: Reassessing Reversal of Adversary to S.E.C.
articles.snippet: The Court of Appeals’ reversal of Judge Jed Rakoff’s decision to reject an S.E.C. deal with Citigroup has troubled many lawyers who specialize in securities law.
articles.abstract: The Court of Appeals’ reversal of Judge Jed Rakoff’s decision to reject an S.E.C. deal with Citigroup has troubled many lawyers who specialize in securities law.
articles.lead_paragraph: Judge Jed S. Rakoff of the Federal District Court in Manhattan sent shock waves through the legal and financial establishments in November 2011 when he rejected a proposed $285 million settlement between the Securities and Exchange Commission and Citigroup. Judge Rakoff said it was impossible for him to say whether it was “fair and reasonable,” let alone in the public interest, after the bank “neither admitted nor denied” the S.E.C.’s accusations nor otherwise revealed any of the facts in a complex mortgage fraud case.

articles.headline: The Snakes May Not Bite, but the Humidity Devours
articles.snippet: England was among the teams less than enthusiastic to play World Cup games in Manaus, this hot, humid city in the Amazon, even with no snakes in sight.
articles.abstract: England was among the teams less than enthusiastic to play World Cup games in Manaus, this hot, humid city in the Amazon, even with no snakes in sight.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANAUS, Brazil — It is the one place all 32 teams probably wanted to avoid in the World Cup, this Amazon city where the heat and humidity feel like a dryer full of damp clothes.

articles.headline: High Cost to Focusing on Student Loans Over Saving
articles.snippet: Taking on debt to pay for college leads many young people to forgo saving money for years — potentially sacrificing hundreds of thousands of dollars.
articles.abstract: Taking on debt to pay for college leads many young people to forgo saving money for years — potentially sacrificing hundreds of thousands of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, President Obama ordered changes to the federal student loan program that could help millions of borrowers make their payments more affordable starting in December 2015.

articles.headline: Settlement Talks Stall for Citigroup and Justice Department
articles.snippet: Talks to settle a civil inquiry into the sale of shoddy mortgage investments have deteriorated, as the sides are deadlocked on how much money the bank should pay.
articles.abstract: Talks to settle a civil inquiry into the sale of shoddy mortgage investments have deteriorated, as the sides are deadlocked on how much money the bank should pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:21 p.m. | Talks between the Justice Department and Citigroup to settle a civil investigation into its sale of shoddy mortgage investments have deteriorated in recent days, as the sides are deadlocked on how much money the bank should pay.

articles.headline: Scoring Onslaught Does In Defending Champions
articles.snippet: Spain, winners of the last World Cup, limped off in defeat as the Dutch triumphed in the remake of the 2010 final as a horror film.
articles.abstract: Spain, winners of the last World Cup, limped off in defeat as the Dutch triumphed in the remake of the 2010 final as a horror film.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALVADOR, Brazil — Sitting on the bench, worrying that history might be repeated at his team’s expense, Dirk Kuyt, the Dutch reserve forward, had a perfect view of a goal that energized a nation and a tournament with its daring and flair.

articles.headline: High-End Hermès Handbags at Center of Suit Against Christie’s
articles.snippet: The venerable auction house has been sued by a rival, Heritage Auctions, after it hired several employees in Heritage’s highly lucrative accessories department.
articles.abstract: The venerable auction house has been sued by a rival, Heritage Auctions, after it hired several employees in Heritage’s highly lucrative accessories department.
articles.lead_paragraph: Locked behind glass, illuminated like a jewel, lies an Hermès Birkin — totem of wealth, bestower of status, and one seriously expensive handbag.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and George Gene Gustines

articles.headline: Obama Finds He Can’t Put Iraq War Behind Him
articles.snippet: Iraq continues to shape President Obama’s tenure, as he concludes that American interests there prevent him from fully leaving the country to the Iraqis themselves.
articles.abstract: Iraq continues to shape President Obama’s tenure, as he concludes that American interests there prevent him from fully leaving the country to the Iraqis themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a high-profile speech to Army cadets last month, President Obama tried to move beyond America’s tumultuous adventures in Iraq and Afghanistan with a new doctrine all but forswearing the use of military power except in the most dire of circumstances.

articles.headline: Oil Industry in Iraq Faces Setback to Revival
articles.snippet: “The collapse of Iraq would bring an international oil crisis,” an expert says, but so far the oil markets are taking the growing unrest in stride.
articles.abstract: “The collapse of Iraq would bring an international oil crisis,” an expert says, but so far the oil markets are taking the growing unrest in stride.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a long history of wars and sanctions, Iraq re-emerged as a critical source of oil in recent years. Mounting Iraqi production helped to ease world oil prices despite the tightening restrictions on Iran and tanking exports from Libya. And Western and Chinese oil companies rushed back, revitalizing long-neglected oil fields in the north and south.

articles.headline: Getting a Good Table by Flicking an App, Not Greasing a Palm
articles.snippet: Restaurateurs are uncomfortable with a wave of mobile apps that secure and resell coveted tables at popular establishments, sometimes covertly.
articles.abstract: Restaurateurs are uncomfortable with a wave of mobile apps that secure and resell coveted tables at popular establishments, sometimes covertly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Who owns a restaurant reservation?

articles.headline: Seeing Their Gains at Risk, Shiites Flock to Join Militias
articles.snippet: Skills honed on behalf of President Bashar al-Assad will be used for militia groups battling the Sunnis who are driving toward Baghdad.
articles.abstract: Skills honed on behalf of President Bashar al-Assad will be used for militia groups battling the Sunnis who are driving toward Baghdad.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — When he heard on Tuesday that Mosul, Iraq’s second-largest city, had fallen to Sunni militants, Abu Ali Alakabaie knew what he had to do.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Rod Nordland

articles.headline: Pension Funds, Dancing a Two-Step With Ratings Firms
articles.snippet: Some government pension funds are suing ratings agencies — but are still relying on them to grade investments.
articles.abstract: Some government pension funds are suing ratings agencies — but are still relying on them to grade investments.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pension fund investors lost billions of dollars trusting the rosy credit ratings stamped on troubled mortgage securities before the 2008 crisis. In its aftermath, they have spent years and many dollars suing Moody’s and Standard & Poor’s, the main purveyors of those dubious grades.

articles.headline: Allergan, Defending Its Fort Botox
articles.snippet: The feisty chief of Allergan, Botox’s maker, says a takeover would imperil the company’s drug-discovery mission.
articles.abstract: The feisty chief of Allergan, Botox’s maker, says a takeover would imperil the company’s drug-discovery mission.
articles.lead_paragraph: David E. I. Pyott spent a couple of hectic days in Manhattan last week, paying calls on institutional investors and Wall Street analysts, trying to persuade them that his company is worth much more than $54 billion.

articles.headline: A Cantor Effect for Businesses and the G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Eric Cantor’s defeat last week in a primary to David Brat, who campaigned against Wall Street, led industry to mobilize to preserve its clout in Congress.
articles.abstract: Eric Cantor’s defeat last week in a primary to David Brat, who campaigned against Wall Street, led industry to mobilize to preserve its clout in Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The day after Representative Eric Cantor became the first congressional leader in modern times to lose his seat in a primary, one of the biggest aftershocks occurred not on Capitol Hill or in the sprawling Richmond suburbs he has represented for more than a decade but on the New York Stock Exchange.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Shaila Dewan

articles.headline: Syria Suicide Bombing Puts U.S. Face on Jihad Video
articles.snippet: American officials believe a recruitment video circulating in extremist circles shows the American who killed dozens in a recent attack, and they are concerned that others will follow in his path.
articles.abstract: American officials believe a recruitment video circulating in extremist circles shows the American who killed dozens in a recent attack, and they are concerned that others will follow in his path.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Like a trailer for a summer blockbuster, the video begins with loud music and the words “Coming Soon.”

articles.headline: A Piece of the Game Beyond the Walls
articles.snippet: Dozens of inmates manufacture soccer balls at a Brazilian prison near one of the 12 cities hosting the World Cup games.
articles.abstract: Dozens of inmates manufacture soccer balls at a Brazilian prison near one of the 12 cities hosting the World Cup games.
articles.lead_paragraph: CONTAGEM, Brazil — Hugo Alves used to play professional soccer for a living. He remains connected to the sport, but not in the way he intended. Now his uniform consists of a red T-shirt and pants, and he makes soccer balls at a factory in prison.

articles.headline: Rebels’ Fast Strike in Iraq Was Years in the Making
articles.snippet: The group’s sweep into Mosul and farther south appeared to catch many Iraqi and U.S. officials by surprise, but the gains were the realization of a yearslong strategy of state-building.
articles.abstract: The group’s sweep into Mosul and farther south appeared to catch many Iraqi and U.S. officials by surprise, but the gains were the realization of a yearslong strategy of state-building.
articles.lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — When Islamic militants rampaged through the Iraqi city of Mosul last week, robbing banks of hundreds of millions of dollars, opening the gates of prisons and burning army vehicles, some residents greeted them as if they were liberators and threw rocks at retreating Iraqi soldiers.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango, Kareem Fahim and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: Tim Cook, Making Apple His Own
articles.snippet: While the company’s enthusiasts impatiently await new wizardry, the new chief executive is trying to make the brand bigger than the next big iThing.
articles.abstract: While the company’s enthusiasts impatiently await new wizardry, the new chief executive is trying to make the brand bigger than the next big iThing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tim Cook, Apple’s chief executive, was an adolescent boy in a small Alabama town in the early 1970s when he saw something he couldn’t forget.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: Massacre Claim Shakes Iraq
articles.snippet: Insurgents from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria posted photos on the web to support the claim that they had executed 1,700 people. If true, it would be the region’s worst mass atrocity in recent years.
articles.abstract: Insurgents from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria posted photos on the web to support the claim that they had executed 1,700 people. If true, it would be the region’s worst mass atrocity in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Wielding the threat of sectarian slaughter, Sunni Islamist militants claimed on Sunday that they had massacred hundreds of captive Shiite members of Iraq’s security forces, posting grisly pictures of a mass execution in Tikrit as evidence and warning of more killing to come.
articles.byline: By Rod Nordland and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: Where Dishonesty Is Best Policy, U.S. Soccer Falls Short
articles.snippet: American players do not fake injuries or exaggerate contact nearly as much as others do, perhaps putting the squad at a strategic disadvantage.
articles.abstract: American players do not fake injuries or exaggerate contact nearly as much as others do, perhaps putting the squad at a strategic disadvantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: NATAL, Brazil — The list of improvements that the United States men’s soccer team needs to make is considerable. Coach Jurgen Klinsmann would like to see a more consistent back line, better touch from his midfielders and plenty more production from the attackers.

articles.headline: Obama Pushes Iraqis to Mend Sectarian Rifts
articles.snippet: The United States has asked Iraq’s prime minister to work with the Kurds to persuade the Sunni minority that the next government will be an “ally not an adversary,” an administration official said.
articles.abstract: The United States has asked Iraq’s prime minister to work with the Kurds to persuade the Sunni minority that the next government will be an “ally not an adversary,” an administration official said.
articles.lead_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — As President Obama weighs airstrikes against marauding militants in Iraq, he has concluded that any American military action must be conditioned on a political plan to try to heal Iraq’s sectarian rifts, a senior administration official said on Sunday.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: For Fox, Much Is Riding on 3 Sequels to ‘Avatar’
articles.snippet: The long-awaited screenplays for James Cameron’s three “Avatar” sequels will soon be ready, probably within weeks.
articles.abstract: The long-awaited screenplays for James Cameron’s three “Avatar” sequels will soon be ready, probably within weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Like the deep-sea craft James Cameron used to dive nearly seven miles down in the Pacific, the long-awaited screenplays for his three sequels to “Avatar” will soon pop to the surface, probably within weeks.

articles.headline: Eric Cantor’s Defeat Exposed a Beltway Journalism Blind Spot
articles.snippet: The provincialism of Washington, D.C., is now multiplied by the diminution of nonnational newspapers.
articles.abstract: The provincialism of Washington, D.C., is now multiplied by the diminution of nonnational newspapers.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s now clear why the primary defeat of the House majority leader, Eric Cantor, came so completely out of the blue last week: Beltway blindness that put a focus on fund-raising, power-brokering and partisan back-and-forth created a reality distortion field that obscured the will of the people.

articles.headline: With an Amazon Smartphone, the Retailer Seeks a Tether to Consumers
articles.snippet: Amazon is set to give the brutal phone business a shot. On the one hand, analysts say, it has no choice; on the other, the rewards could be tremendous.
articles.abstract: Amazon is set to give the brutal phone business a shot. On the one hand, analysts say, it has no choice; on the other, the rewards could be tremendous.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hold the phone: Amazon wants to burrow even deeper into your life.

articles.headline: Bank Tool Is Expanding Unbanked Households, Regulators Say
articles.snippet: New York’s attorney general is taking aim at databases that have been criticized for limiting access to banking services.
articles.abstract: New York’s attorney general is taking aim at databases that have been criticized for limiting access to banking services.
articles.lead_paragraph: In her early college years, when Charlette Williams started routinely mismanaging her finances and pushing her checking account balance into the red, she never thought the mistakes would haunt her five years later, she said. Now, she is paying a steep price.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Agency Aims to Regulate Map Aids in Vehicles
articles.snippet: In an effort to curb distracted driving, a measure in a proposed bill would specify that Transportation Department could regulate smartphone map apps and systems built into cars.
articles.abstract: In an effort to curb distracted driving, a measure in a proposed bill would specify that Transportation Department could regulate smartphone map apps and systems built into cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: Getting directions on the road from Google Maps and other smartphone apps is a popular alternative to the expensive navigation aids included in some cars. The apps are also a gray area when it comes to laws banning the use of cellphones or texting while driving.

articles.headline: V.A. Punished Critics on Staff, Doctors Assert
articles.snippet: In response to employee whistle-blowers, the Department of Veterans Affairs has made clear over the years that it would not hesitate to retaliate, disciplining and even firing those who spoke up.
articles.abstract: In response to employee whistle-blowers, the Department of Veterans Affairs has made clear over the years that it would not hesitate to retaliate, disciplining and even firing those who spoke up.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Staff members at dozens of Department of Veterans Affairs hospitals across the country have objected for years to falsified patient appointment schedules and other improper practices, only to be rebuffed, disciplined or even fired after speaking up, according to interviews with current and former staff members and internal documents.

articles.headline: A Nemesis in the Black Stars
articles.snippet: The United States will face off on Monday against Ghana, in a matchup that over the last decade has turned into an unexpected rivalry. Victory for the Americans would be a long time coming.
articles.abstract: The United States will face off on Monday against Ghana, in a matchup that over the last decade has turned into an unexpected rivalry. Victory for the Americans would be a long time coming.
articles.lead_paragraph: NATAL, Brazil — For more than two days straight here in this beach town in northeastern Brazil, the rain came down with the strength of an open fire hose. It shook the cashew trees and bent the palm trees so that their fronds nearly kissed the ground. It turned roads into rivers, caused mudslides and turned some neighborhood soccer fields into ponds.

articles.headline: Population Shifts Turning All Politics National
articles.snippet: Growth in Mississippi and Virginia fueled by a migration of newcomers from other parts of the country and even abroad is bringing nationalized politics to races further down the ballot.
articles.abstract: Growth in Mississippi and Virginia fueled by a migration of newcomers from other parts of the country and even abroad is bringing nationalized politics to races further down the ballot.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOUTHAVEN, Miss. — When William E. Davis was growing up here in DeSoto County, just across the state line from Memphis, there were more than 300 dairy farms, and he was raised on one of them.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Argentina’s Debt Appeal Is Rejected by Supreme Court
articles.snippet: The developments are likely to add to the turmoil in Argentina’s already unsettled bond market.
articles.abstract: The developments are likely to add to the turmoil in Argentina’s already unsettled bond market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:57 p.m. | The Supreme Court handed Argentina two major defeats on Monday in cases brought by bondholders who refused to accept reduced payments after the country’s 2001 default.
